subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}

Originally {{zh-l|*ã¤…}}, a {{Han compound|æ—¡|å¿ƒ|ls=psc|c1=p|c2=s|t2=heart|nocap=1}}.

As early as the Qin dynasty, a meaningless component {{zh-l|*å¤Š|foot}} was added to the bottom of the character, as with some other characters depicting people. Compare {{zh-l|*æ†‚}} (from {{zh-l|*ã¥‘}}).

Further corruption turned the original phonetic {{zh-l|*æ—¡}} into {{lang|zh|â¿±çˆ«å†–}}.

subSections.title: Definitions
Usage notes
subSections.text: * When used for people, {{lang|zh|æ„›}}ï¼{{lang|zh|çˆ±}} usually refers to romantic love. When used like this, older Mandarin speakers often describe the use of this term as overly {{zh-l|è‚‰éº»|cheesy}}. For this reason, the word {{zh-l|å–œæ­¡|to like}} might be used instead. Using the word {{zh-l|å–œæ­¡}} literally means ''like'', but when used in a romantic context (especially boyfriend/girlfriend), it actually means love. However, younger Mandarin speakers seem to have been influenced somewhat by Western culture, and are now using the verb {{lang|zh|æ„›}}ï¼{{lang|zh|çˆ±}} much more often than was socially acceptable in the past.

Originally a compound of {{compound|ja|sort=ã¾ãª|çœŸ|tr1=ma|t1=true, genuine|ãª|tr2=na}}, an {{inh|ja|ojp|-|sort=ã¾ãª}} version of modern {{cog|ja|ã®|tr=no|pos=possessive particle}}.<ref name="KDJ"/> The use of {{lang|ja|æ„›}} here is an example of [[ateji]].
